captions.text:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1038\cocoasubrtf360
{\fonttbl\f0\fswiss\fcharset0 Helvetica;}

{\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;}
\margl1440\margr1440\vieww12440\viewh13540\viewkind0
\pard\tx720\tx1440\tx2160\tx2880\tx3600\tx4320\tx5040\tx5760\tx6480\tx7200\tx7920\tx8640\ql\qnatural\pardirnatural

\f0\fs32 \cf0 What happens if an immovable
object meets an unstoppable force? Is a popular

question on the internet.\
\

Of course, relativity clearly tells us that
there is no such thing as an immovable object

- here's why: If you pick any supposedly immovable
object, or just something like your house

or the earth, I can make it move. All I need
to do is start to move relative to it, for

example I might ride a rocket, and suddenly
from my perspective, I'm not moving and the

earth sails by outside. The laws of physics
make no preference for inertial frame of reference,

so from my perspective here, I do not stir,
and yet it's clear: the immovable object moves!

So because of relativity, "immovable objects"
cannot be. But what I think people normally

MEAN by "immovable object" is something that
if it's not moving, you can't make it start

moving by Pushing on it. So, not an immovable
object, but an "un-acceleratable" one.\

\
Using Newton's second law, we know that an

object's acceleration is equal to the total
force on it divided by its mass (though you've

probably seen this as F=ma). So an "un-acceleratable"
object would be an object with infinite mass;

an object so massive that no matter how big
the total force F is, when you divide F by

m you always get zero.\
\

Of course, as we've said, not being able to
accelerate an object doesn't necessarily mean

that the object isn't moving - it just means
that you can't directly change its speed - if

it's not moving, then it'll stay not moving.
And if it's moving at 100 miles an hour, then

it'll stay moving at 100 miles per hour.\
\

So, what about an unstoppable force? Well,
all the fundamental forces in nature are actually

caused by particles (like photons or gluons
or gravitons) that interact with an object

and change its momentum - the only way to
NOT be affected by a force is to not interact

with it at all (like how electrons don't interact
with gluons so they aren't subject to the

strong nuclear force). Even light itself is
an unstoppable force - every photon that hits

your body changes your momentum a tiny little
bit, and there's nothing you can do about

it other than avoid light altogether or become
transparent.\

\
So all forces are already unstoppable\'85

but my impression is that the phrase "unstoppable
force" isn't really meant to imply anything

about "forces" like electromagnetism or gravity,
but rather, something that you cannot stop

from barreling down on you. That is, an object
whose velocity cannot be changed by pushing

on it.\
\

So, IF by an unstoppable force we mean an
object moving at a speed that can never be

changed, then that means the object cannot
accelerate\'85 but wait a second, this sounds

familiar! Recalling what we learned earlier,
an unstoppable force must be an un-acceleratable

object! And that means that an "unstoppable
force" and an "immovable object" are really

just the same, viewed from different reference
frames!\

\
Now, since infinite mass requires infinite

energy, we don't know of anything in the universe
that behaves like this, not the least because

it would automatically be a black hole so
big that everything in the universe would

already be inside of it.\'85 but what if we
ignored gravity and imagined there WERE an

un-acceleratable object? Well, first it would
be a source of infinite free power and would

allow us to live in a 100% happy utopian society
and break the second law of thermodynamics

and probably create portals and time travel,
too (you can do a lot with infinite energy).

But more importantly, if two of these infinitely
massive un-acceleratable objects were moving

towards each other and collided, then since
by definition it's not possible for the velocity

of either of them to change, the only possibility
is that they must pass right through each
other with no effect on each other at all.}

title: Immovable Object vs. Unstoppable Force - Which Wins?

comments.text:
Immoveable object, mass = infinity.
Unstoppable force, force = infinity.
Acceleration = force/mass.
Acceleration = infinity/infinity
Acceleration = 1
Therefore it accelerates at 1 metre per second squared.﻿

comments.text:
Gravity is also an unstoppable force, yet I'm still standing still. An 
object with an unstoppable force simply stops from our perspective by the 
immovable object, but while this is happening, the unstoppable force is 
still applying force to the immovable object. The unstoppable force is 
therefore never 'stopped'.﻿

3.) moreover the whole concept is based heavily on circular reasoning:

comments.author: Jacinto Williams

comments.text:
+Jacinto Williams talking about electrons, neutrinos is one thing... 

But *Immovable Object vs unstoppable force* is a well known paradox... And 
its based on solid material... Like, a meteor vs a moon or a small planet 
(Dwarf)... Not exactly science/Quantum physics... Thus making it impossible 
to go through each other (as we haven't found a source of material that 
allows this to be possible)
comments.author: portucito7

comments.text:
Many objects on the quantum level can pass through each other's local area, 
or even exist within the same localised point; although some subatomic 
particles experience certain quantum 'rules' that prevent them from doing 
this (Pauli exclusion principle acting on electrons, electrostatic 
repulsion of like charge acting on protons, strong nuclear force 
repulsion acting on neutrons, ETC...), others can pass through each other.

For example, two electrons can occupy the same point in space 
simultaneously, provided that they are of an opposite spin to each other 
(which technically puts them in different "locations", as a 'spin' is 
actually another dimension, which makes perfect sense), neutrinos only 
interact with larger particles, such as protons, not each other, and pions? 
Let's just say that they've got no qualms about going wherever the fuck 
they damn well please.

The concept that two objects can't occupy a single point in space 
simultaneously is only our perception of the material world, which biases 
our thinking. This is one of the main reasons why people call quantum 
physics hard. Although to be fair, it is difficult, but not for the reasons 
people think. Once you get thinking about it, it makes more sense that two 
objects can occupy the same point in space. After all, an object isn't 
where it is, it's *what* it is.

Good luck reading my wall of text :P

comments.text:
Why does noone ever explain this? Hold your horses, you hosers. What I mean 
is that everybody starts harping on the fucking "omg immovable 
object/unstoppable force does not exist, and I'll tell you why, 
ladidadidaaaa."

Shut up already...

On the internet an "unstoppable force" is commonly perceived as an object 
moving at a certain speed (irrelevant speed, might I add).

An "immovable object" is an object that cannot be moved. 

So far, so hard for people like MinutePhysics...

So what happens when the immovable object meets the unstoppable force? 
Annihilation. Complete opposites always end up in annihilation. Simple as 
that. If you take the electron as the unstoppable force and the positron as 
the immovable object and make them collide you get... you guessed it - 
Annihilation. 

Now, I know that the existence of an unstoppable force and an immovable 
object at the same time at any given point ever, ever would fundamentally 
break physics and everything ever. Don't get me wrong, I know an immovable 
object does not exist. For every action there is an equal and opposite 
reaction. And I know I'll contradict myself in a second here but this kind 
of makes sense: If an immovable object exist so must an unstoppable force.

WarpRulez explains it quite well with the knowledge of physics that the 
human race possesses. You won't get any closer to solving the "Unstoppable 
Force vs Immovable Object" conundrum.﻿

If Stephen Hawking's theory from the Thorne - Preskill bet on quantum 
information and black holes were true, then perhaps the same could be 
applied to the scenario, in that the object being acted on would divert 
itself to another dimension/universe in order to obey both constants 
(unbreakable still applies to self, and the force acting would still be 
unstoppable, albeit no longer acting on its initial target).

Then again, how many dimensions can you run to until the unstoppable force 
finds you??? O.O

force carrying particle that accelerates all particles. Then, the answer to

logical consistency.﻿

comments.author: Nikolas Peesker

comments.text:
An unmovable object = an object which has a fixed place in this reality. 
You walking around the object isn't the object moving, its you moving your 
frame of reference.
An unstoppable force = A force which is constantly moving everything in any 
given direction. E.g. gravity pulling everything to a specific point.

Those aren't the same things unless you define them in such a way that they 
are the same thing (which is easy to do with anything).﻿
